DataElement.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Collaborative Staging Neoplasm Size Extent Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Records how the codes for the two items CS Tumor Size (2800) and CS Extension (2810) were determined, based on the diagnostic methods employed.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Collaborative Staging Neoplasm Coding
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Records how the codes for "CS Tumor Size" [2800] and "CS Extension" [2810] were determined based on the diagnostic methods employed.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.:The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.
The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Property.preferredDefinition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits).:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.:The activity of implementing rules that are used to map the elements of one set onto the elements of another set, usually on a one-to-one basis. (from Wikipedia)

Concepts.definition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits).

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The activity of implementing rules that are used to map the elements of one set onto the elements of another set, usually on a one-to-one basis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Removed special characters for MDR data migration. 3.9.20 mc

ValueDomain.preferredName: Collaborative Staging Neoplasm Size Extent  Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits)._(TOO-mer) An abnormal mass of tissue that results from excessive cell division. Tumors perform no useful body function. They may be benign (not cancerous) or malignant (cancerous)._The activity of implementing rules that are used to map the elements of one set onto the elements of another set, usually on a one-to-one basis. (from Wikipedia)_Size; the physical magnitude of something._The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time._A system of numbered categories for representation of data. [Explanatory Comment: See the Collaborative Staging Manual and Coding Instructions, Verision 1.0, for site-specific codes and coding rules.]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

Concepts.definition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits).

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: Division of Cancer Control and Population Sciences

ReferenceDocuments.name: Coding Information
ReferenceDocuments.description: See Collaborative Stage (CS) Data Collection System for rules and site-specific codes and coding sructures.

ReferenceDocuments.name: CS Tumor Size/Ext Eval Description
ReferenceDocuments.description: This belongs to the set of Collaborative Staging (CS) data items effective with 2004 diagnosis. This data item is used in CS to identify whether the T (of AJCC TNM) was clinically or pathologically diagnosed and by what method, "CS Tumor Size/Ext Eval" is used to derive the Derived AJCC T Descriptor [2950].

ReferenceDocuments.name: NAACCR 12.1, Data Stds/Dict.
